DOC.HEAD: Neighbors Sue to Muffle Church's Carillon
DOC.TEXT: A new church chime that rings and plays hymns during the day frightens dogs and birds and wakes small children from their naps, says a neighborhood group that wants the electronic bells silenced. ``It's like having a grandfather clock with monster speakers put in the middle of your home without your permission,'' said Vaughan Pritchett, who lives two doors away. Pritchett said Monday the three couples who sued tried to negotiate with Bellshire United Methodist Church for two months but could not reach a compromise. He said he regrets the holiday timing of the suit, but he wants the Christmas hymns and other melodies toned down. The carillon was installed in September with $7,700 donated by a former church member in memory of her son, said the Rev. Stephen Smith, pastor at Bellshire. The bells are played from four speakers each day until early evening. They strike the hour six times a day and play hymns three times. ``We have half a dozen people who live as close to the church as these people do, who love the carillon,'' he said. ``We could raise the volume a lot higher, but we're respecting the neighbors,'' Smith said. ``We did respect the neighbor who goes to bed early, and we quit striking the hour at 7 p.m.'' A letter filed with the lawsuit from Walter H. Collins, a public health environmentalist, said a test in September showed the bells were louder than a typical freight train heard from a distance of 100 feet. A court hearing was scheduled for Jan. 3.
